pullrequest.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

pull_request.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

update.description:
Add mex (MATLAB / Octave) wrappers for the C functions in the new sim API.  Notes:

* ~~At the time of writing, for clarity this PR is targeted at the `sim_api` branch, upon which it relies.  Once `sim_api` is merged, this PR should be retargeted at `default`.~~
* ~~A major missing piece of this PR is documentation in each `.m` file that explains parameters and return values for each function.~~
* ~~Also missing is an example of how to use the functions.~~
* `hxs_example.m` demonstrates most API calls.
* ~~Currently missing is a test of this code (it will go into handsim).~~
* There's a [handsim PR](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/112) that uses `hxs_example.m` as a test.

Following @jacquelinekay 's example, here's a breakdown of review responsibility (for each, please check the implementation in `hxgz.c` and the function definition and documentation in the corresponding `hxs_*.m` file):

* @caguero: `hxs_add_model, hxs_remove_model, hxs_is_logging, hxs_start_logging, hxs_stop_logging, hxs_set_model_color, hxs_model_color`
* @scpeters: `hxs_model_collide_mode, hxs_set_model_collide_mode, hxs_contacts, hxs_set_model_joint_state, hxs_set_model_link_state`
* @hsu: `hxs_model_transform, hxs_set_model_transform, hxs_angular_velocity, hxs_set_angular_velocity, hxs_linear_velocity, hxs_set_linear_velocity, hxs_sim_info`
* @jacquelinekay: `hxs_reset, hxs_apply_force, hxs_apply_wrench, hxs_apply_torque,  hxs_camera_transform, hxs_set_camera_transform, hxs_model_gravity_mode, hxs_set_model_gravity_mode, hxs_example`

---

To test this code in Octave on Linux:

* `sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev` (to get the `mkoctfile` compiler)
* configure, make, and install
* `gazebo worlds/arat.world`
* `cd <prefix>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave`
* `octave`

Now, at the Octave prompt, you can try any of the `hxs_*.m` functions, without the `.m` suffix.  E.g., try `hxs_sim_info`.  To run the example: `hxs_example`.
update.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

pullrequest.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

content.raw:
f78645d uses `fprintf` to format the output, which now looks like this:

~~~
Models:
  ground_plane
    Links:
      link
    Joints:
  table
    Links:
      link
    Joints:
  wooden_case
    Links:
      base
      lid
    Joints:
      lid_hinge
~~~
content.html:
f78645d uses fprintf to format the output, which now looks like this:

Models:
  ground_plane
    Links:
      link
    Joints:
  table
    Links:
      link
    Joints:
  wooden_case
    Links:
      base
      lid
    Joints:
      lid_hinge

content.raw: I don't think so, because we checked above that `nrhs == 4`, which means that `prhs[3]` must be populated.  Given that check, I don't know of a circumstance in which `mxGetPr` would return NULL.
content.html: I don't think so, because we checked above that nrhs == 4, which means that prhs[3] must be populated. Given that check, I don't know of a circumstance in which mxGetPr would return NULL.

content.raw: Similar to the comment about `mxGetPr` vs `mxGetData`: yes, I think that it would be more correct to use the API calls that are specific to integers, but passing doubles around like this seems to work fine, so I'm inclined to leave it as is.  If anybody encounters (or can predict) a problem with this method, then I'll happily change it.
content.html: Similar to the comment about mxGetPr vs mxGetData: yes, I think that it would be more correct to use the API calls that are specific to integers, but passing doubles around like this seems to work fine, so I'm inclined to leave it as is. If anybody encounters (or can predict) a problem with this method, then I'll happily change it.

content.html: I don't know. So far, I've just been blindly assigning to plhs[0] and it works. To be honest, I don't understand how MATLAB handles allocation for the return arguments.

content.raw: Not really.  I think that it would be better to use [mxGetData](http://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/apiref/mxgetdata.html) and appropriately cast the result.  But this method seems to work OK, so I'm inclined to leave it for now.
content.html: Not really. I think that it would be better to use mxGetData and appropriately cast the result. But this method seems to work OK, so I'm inclined to leave it for now.

pull_request.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

pullrequest.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

content.raw:
I made a few changes to make the example work on MATLAB in 137863c . Summary:

* MATLAB doesn't like double quotes for string literals. It prefers single quotes.
* There is no autoincrement (and friends) operator.
* There's no `sleep()`. The alternative is `pause()` that we learned before is not really accurate.
content.html:
I made a few changes to make the example work on MATLAB in 137863c . Summary:

  • MATLAB doesn't like double quotes for string literals. It prefers single quotes.
  • There is no autoincrement (and friends) operator.
  • There's no sleep(). The alternative is pause() that we learned before is not really accurate.

Now, at the Octave prompt, you can try any of the `hxs_*.m` functions, without the `.m` suffix.  E.g., try `hxs_sim_info`.  To run the example: `hxs_example`.

update.description:
Add mex (MATLAB / Octave) wrappers for the C functions in the new sim API.  Notes:

* ~~At the time of writing, for clarity this PR is targeted at the `sim_api` branch, upon which it relies.  Once `sim_api` is merged, this PR should be retargeted at `default`.~~
* ~~A major missing piece of this PR is documentation in each `.m` file that explains parameters and return values for each function.~~
* ~~Also missing is an example of how to use the functions.~~
* `hxs_example.m` demonstrates most API calls.
* ~~Currently missing is a test of this code (it will go into handsim).~~
* There's a [handsim PR](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/112) that uses `hxs_example.m` as a test.

Following @jacquelinekay 's example, here's a breakdown of review responsibility (for each, please check the implementation in `hxgz.c` and the function definition and documentation in the corresponding `hxs_*.m` file):

* @caguero: `hxs_add_model, hxs_remove_model, hxs_is_logging, hxs_start_logging, hxs_stop_logging, hxs_set_model_color, hxs_model_color`
* @scpeters: `hxs_model_collide_mode, hxs_set_model_collide_mode, hxs_contacts, hxs_set_model_joint_state, hxs_set_model_link_state`
* @hsu: `hxs_model_transform, hxs_set_model_transform, hxs_angular_velocity, hxs_set_angular_velocity, hxs_linear_velocity, hxs_set_linear_velocity, hxs_sim_info`
* @jacquelinekay: `hxs_reset, hxs_apply_force, hxs_apply_wrench, hxs_apply_torque,  hxs_camera_transform, hxs_set_camera_transform, hxs_model_gravity_mode, hxs_set_model_gravity_mode, hxs_example`

---

To test this code in Octave on Linux:

* `sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev` (to get the `mkoctfile` compiler)
* configure, make, and install
* `gazebo worlds/arat.world`
* `cd <prefix>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave`
* `octave`

Now, at the Octave prompt, you can try any of the `hxs_*.m` functions, without the `.m` suffix.  E.g., try `hxs_sim_info`.  To run the example: `hxs_example`.

content.raw:
Got this error while running `hxs_example`:

```
hxs_apply_torque() Service call timed out.
error:  
error: called from:
error:   /home/jackie/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hxs_apply_torque.m at line 18, column 3
error:   /home/jackie/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hxs_example.m at line 132, column 1
```

This is probably the fault of the Gazebo implementation. I'll check it out.
content.html:
Got this error while running hxs_example:

hxs_apply_torque() Service call timed out.
error:  
error: called from:
error:   /home/jackie/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hxs_apply_torque.m at line 18, column 3
error:   /home/jackie/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hxs_example.m at line 132, column 1

This is probably the fault of the Gazebo implementation. I'll check it out.
